fields.title: May 10, 2013 7:25am
fields.textContent: RT @Microsoft Research India Designing ICT systems for rural users in the developing world can be very hard. Just a few of the challenges we face are low literacy, limited experience using digital technologies, and the wide variability in spoken languages. To overcome some of these issues, we created VideoKheti (http://research.microsoft.com/apps/pubs/default.aspx?id=183489), a mobile system that uses speech, graphics, and touch interaction to help low-literate farmers in rural India find and watch agricultural extension videos in their own language and dialect.

fields.textContent: RIkin Gandhi's (CEO of Digital Green) thoughts about Farmers:  Farmers have shown me that our connection to the Earth and to one another is both a source of strength and fragility.  Farmers may be the largest community of small business men and women, but they also face some of the greatest uncertainties - from weather to markets to government policies.  But having dealt with such vagaries from one day to the next and from generation to generation, farmers are also among the most resilient individuals in the world.

fields.title: Climbing beans improve life for Rwandan farmers – in pictures
fields.textContent: Already one of the most densely populated countries in Africa, the UN predicts that Rwanda’s population will quadruple by 2100, placing increasing pressure on the limited agricultural land. While beans are a staple food crop in the country, traditional bush beans produce poor yields and cannot support the country’s current population, innovative climbing beans are being used to achieve better yield.

fields.title: Digital Green: Indian Idol for Farmers
fields.textContent:
Meet the AFI Growth Challenge Participants — Check out the changeshop for Digital Green: Indian Idol for Farmers at the AFI Changemakers Community. Digital Green was represented at our Jan 2012 inaugural forum in New Delhi by Rikin Gandhi and Vinay Kumar, two of AFI’s 100 Young Social Innovators (YSIs). 

Digital Green works towards improving food security and alleviating rural poverty by producing and disseminating videos by farmers, for farmers, and of farmers on locally relevant agricultural information. Its communication model blends technology and social organization to bring about behavior change, which empowers individuals to sustainably increase their productivities and incomes.

Digital Green's network of partners and communities have produced over 2,200 videos and reached out to 100,000 farmers across 1,100 villages in India. Over the next 3.5 years, Digital Green aims to reach at least 1 million farmers across 10,000 villages in India and other parts of South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa. Digital Green model has been shown to increase the efficiency of agriculture extension agencies by 20%. 

Join Digital Green and other innovative Social Enterprises by setting up your changeshop at http://www.changemakers.com/community/afi before 1st June 2012.

fields.title: Digital Green
fields.textContent:
A translation of a newspaper article published in Odisha on a DG training programme: 

Training Programme on Improved Agriculture Practice-

As a part of its Digital Green project, a state level NGO named VARRAT operating in Keonjhar district of Odisha had conducted a training programme on enabling the small and marginal farmers to adopt improved cropping practices through use of ICT based technology. During the programme which was held in the month of Jan, 2012, 37 Village Resource Persons were trained on various processes involved in video production and dissemination. Till date VARRAT has produced 140 such videos and conducted dissemination in 110 villages of 3 blocks of the district reaching to 6,900 farmers and most of them have benefitted from adopting these practices.

fields.textContent: During my recent trip through rural Bihar and Andhra Pradesh I saw some amazing examples of women growing out of poverty by making agriculture a profitable business rather than seeing it as a way of life that they were born into.

fields.title: Rikin Gandhi, CEO, Digital Green : Social Entrepreneur who disseminates education to farmers through
fields.textContent: Rikin Gandhi was included in the prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Technology Review list of 35 global innovators called TR 35. He is the CEO of Digital Green who make videos to spread the word about best practices in agriculture.
